Bringing together a cross-party group of young Sri Lankan parliamentarians and political representatives; and bringing together diaspora communities in the UK, for an interdependent and positive peace. Engaging cross-community second generation individuals in peacebuilding initiatives, both in Sri Lanka and within the diaspora in the UK.

Consortium partners will focus on four main themes: Inclusive Economic Development, Inclusive Peace Processes, Inclusive and Effective Institutions, and Gender Drivers of Conflict & Peace. There will also be additional resources for cross-programme learning, synthesis and outreach, as well as scope to explore new and emerging issues for research.

1) National and international Peacebuilding actors in Myanmar engaged by the project integrate broader, more comprehensive gender perspectives into their ongoing work and facilitate women's, men's and gender minorities' meaningful participation in peacebuilding.

aggregate analytical overview of the achievement

•	Cooperatives have responded in some cases to CLS advocacy, resulting in reduced taxes, improved facilities and removal of children from mines
o	For example, in Kalehe, the COPAMIHANUBU Cooperative responded to advocacy undertaken by the CLS against the large number of children in its mine sites. At the Fungamwaka, ChezMadame, Filon1 and Filon2 mining sites, the cooperative erected large signs prohibiting children from entering the mining sites and raised awareness until it succeeded in getting 80 children out of the sites and enrolling 5 of the most vulnerable children in school using the cooperative’s own financial means in Lumbishi. This same cooperative has built latrines at these sites to improve hygiene conditions for miners.

•	Madini has engaged initially one-on-one and subsequently in widening circles of private sector influence.  From inception, this has included meeting with key decision makers of the organisations listed below, followed by separate meetings with the FEC South Kivu in South Kivu and a gold exporting comptoir in Ituri.  Concurrently we have engaged with the national FEC Chamber to brief them on common interests in stabilisation and improved mining governance
•	Effective engagement of economic operators have actively participated and contributed to advocacy efforts and Round Tables in Ituri and South Kivu. Key targets of the bilateral and multilateral meetings on this issue include the Congolese Federation of Businesses (Fédération des Entreprises du Congo -FEC), the South Kivu Chamber of Mines, minerals processing entities, cooperatives, and gold buyers. At national level, the project has secured the commitment of senior management of SAKIMA SAR, the Kilomoto Mining Company and Mongbwalu Gold Mine (MGM) have embraced the idea of blue mining status and relations with the Cooperatives, including working agreements and memoranda of understanding with them.

•	IPIS conducted conflict and context analyses in the 5 territories (Shabunda, Fizi, Kalehe in South Kivu and Djugu and Mambasa in Ituri Territory) targeted by the project and produced 11 reports.
•	OGP in South Kivu and Justice Plus in Ituri have facilitated a second level of participatory analysis including both context & conflict by the community itself.
•	8 Local Mining Monitoring Committees (CLS) at Chiefdom level and 12 Local Mining Monitoring Sub-Committees (SCLS) at Groupement level, 1 Territorial Monitoring Committee (CTS) at Mambasa Territory level and 2 Provincial Monitoring Committees (CPS) at the Provincal level have been reinforced or created, and are supported on an ongoing basis.  Ituri CPS has performed well despite military “siege”, assisted by provincial officials’ commitment & Madini facilitation.
o	We are supporting a total of 23 structures (16 in Ituri and 7 in south Kivu). 19 of the structures were created and 4 have been reinforced/revitalized
o	These structures have dealt with 92 incidents out of the 323 reported in the mining sites, referring others to competent authorities . 
•	In Ituri, 5 local security plans (LSPs) were developed in the chiefdoms of Bahema Baguru, Mambisa, Babila Babombi, Babila Bakwanza and Mambasa. In South Kivu, 2 local security plans were developed, one in  Bahavu in Kalehe Territory and the other in Mutambalan Fizi Territory; 1 security assessment was carried out in Bamuguba-Nord, in Shabunda Territory.

•	Kufatilia Platform incident reporting is now operational in all 8 Madini Chiefdoms, feeding real-time data to stakeholders. Since April 2021, IPIS has been implementing the incident reporting system in the zones covered by the Madini project. IPIS has trained 14 local civil society organizations, selected for their knowledge in the artisanal mining and Human rights sector. 4 CSOs based in Ituri (Justice Plus, ADECO, FOMI, CDC) and 6 in South Kivu (OGP, Max Impaxt, FSH, ACADHOSHA, APDE, CENADEP) are directly paid with funding from the Madini project.The grid below shows the number of incidents reported and their status. The situation in Djugu reflects both the omnipresence of violence perpetrated by the CODECO, but also the extreme difficulty for our partners to manage these incidents.
•	Training to FARDC 
The project provided a series of trainings on the mining code and regulations, and human rights. 71% of those trained increased their knowledge about the limits of their responsibilities and their ability to effectively put in good use their recently acquired knowledge on these matters. We had some delays in starting this activity while we finalised the implementation strategy for the training and identified new interlocuters in Ituri (after the imposition of a military siege). The immediate results of the training have been positive cross both provinces. In Fizi, after participating in the training organised by OGP, the commander of the 33003rd regiment undertook an internal investigation to forbid military from visiting mining sites near Mukera. In Kalehe, we collected anecdotal evidence that messaging from FARDC commanders in the area who participated in Madini organised training has led to a ban on soldiers escorting minerals at night, an action which seems to be respected in the axes we are working in. Three policemen were sanctioned in Numbi by the mining police for similar behaviour. In Mambasa, the deputy Territory Administrator, Colonel Maxime TSHISHIMBI, has become very dynamics in the CTS (Local Committee for the Monitoring of Mining Activities), and instructed all elements in military and police uniforms to stop interfering and participating in mining activities. Since this declaration, in the TINDIKA LOKITO mining site (targeted by the project), we noted a total reduction of FARDC and police officers as of December 2021. The deputy AT organizes mining code awareness sessions during police parades.  

•	P-DDRCS linkages created with new leadership at national level, sustained at provincial levels
After waiting for the government’s DDRCS strategy to be released, Madini is in contact with the new national coordinator of the programme and has follow up discussions with the interim provincial leads in South Kivu and Ituri regarding the programme. We have used these audiences to raise awareness of the need for a DDR approach that is realistic and feasible in areas of high mining activity, where economic incentives to remain connected to armed groups remain high. To avoid creating expectations through sensitisation before the programme is fully up and running and before Madini’s own community development projects started, we focused our work around this result area in 2021 on advocacy and strategy influencing. We are also in discussion with the Belgian organisation “Hive” regarding a piece of research that they are undertaking on behalf of the OECD looking at DDR in mining areas; we feel that there are important opportunities to influence the Government of DRC’s new programme to ensure that it is practical and fit for purpose in mining areas, where the types of armed actors that are present and the motivations of members joining are specific/different to other non-mining or natural resource rich regions. We are in discussion with Hive around how Madini can contribute to this research and support in its diffusion next year (for which Hive have little budget/planned activity, especially when it comes to engaging the DRC Government). After some unforeseen delays, the report is due to be released in Q2 of 2022.

•	Regular site monitoring and incident reporting across 182 sites sustained, data integrated into 11 reports 
•	Global (OECD Partner session & EurAC conference) presentations & policy report  conveyed Madini as resource for unlocking qualification constraints for conflict-free exports through Blue Mines & ongoing Emirates gold trafficking problem. The EurAC conference organised in September 2021 brought together comparative input from DRC and from Columbia civil society on the shortcomings of the EU conflict minerals regulations and proposals for improvement and now serves as one of the bases of Madini’s advocacy on this subject. 
o	The link between conflict and responsible artisanal gold and 3T supply chains was highlighted to 120 global stakeholders in conflict mineral supply chains at the OECD Partners Session on April 30, 2021, organized by the Madini Project. 
o	Two reports were distributed to participants: one entitled "Conflict Analysis and Stakeholder Mapping in South-Kivu and Ituri"  and the other "Promoting Clean Production, Trade and Export of Minerals from the DRC as a Driver for Local Peace and Stability” .
o	The later of these two reports, produced  by Levin Sources, also highlights gaps in international regulations, including with the United Arab Emirates, a country that allows gold from conflict zones in the DRC to be recycled into clean gold for entry into the UK and EU markets. Action is needed on this issue at the international, regional, and national levels to build and maintain buyers’ confidence in the DRC gold supply chain. 
•	Effective advocacy on Blue Mines domestication in DRC law by Ministry of Mines has created provincial and national momentum to work on 4 Arretes, to be linked with politically important re-launch of ITOA, the Ministry of Mines gold chain of custody system.  This will open access to 2700 additional ASM sites in eastern DRC, mostly gold. By the end of 2021, one arreté had been signed off and a Ministerial commission within the CEEC continues to work on finalising the three others.

•	The Madini project positioned itself as a credible actor able to facilitate mutual analysis between some of the most influential actors and structures regionally working on harmonising tax regimes – notably the ICGLR and OECD. This we have achieved through our high level research reports (including the regional tax study commissioned by the project and carried out by Levin Sources), building confidence through bilateral engagement as well as visible participation and contribution to the global OECD conference on mining and the ICGLR Khartoum conference in September 2021.Madini's advocacy is based on conflict analysis and emerging policy opportunities, including harmonization of tax regimes and systems of Burundi, DRC, Uganda, and Rwanda. Madini attended an international conference on sustainable minerals exploitation in the Great Lakes Region in Khartoum (Sudan), in August. The conference was organized by the United Nations Special Envoy on mineral resources in the African Great Lakes Region. One of the key issues discussed (and on which Madini passed a series of high level influencing messages) was the joint exploitation of shared resources as a tool for stabilizing the region. Gold and the 3Ts are shared resources between the DRC, Uganda, Rwanda, Burundi and Tanzania. The project has been engaging with the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs as an important stakeholder who has been supporting Madini with new political entry points on regional policy questions. For example, in Bujumbura, Madini was in contact with the Political Counselor / Second Secretary of the Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherlands on the problem of informal or illegal taxes, the strong influence of economic operators on politics that they can influence the vote in the provincial assembly, transparency in the management of tax revenues and contract/title awards
